ExplntnTxt: PART V, SECTION B, LINE 5: MARY LANNING HEALTHCARE CONDUCTED ITS INITIAL COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS ASSESSMENT IN 2012 USING THE MOBILIZING FOR ACTION THROUGH PLANNING AND PARTNERSHIPS (MAPP) PROCESS. THIS WAS CONDUCTED IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE SOUTH HEARTLAND DISTRICT HEALTH DEPARTMENT (SHDHD). THE CURRENT ASSESSMENT, CONDUCTED IN 2015, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH THE SHDHD USED A MINI-MAPP PROCESS FOR THE CHNA. THE ENTIRE MAPP PROCESS WILL BE USED EVERY SIX YEARS IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE SHDHD. ELEMENTS OF THE MINI-MAPP PROCESS INCLUDED A COMMUNITY THEMES AND STRENGTHS SURVEY, HEALTH STATUS ASSESSMENT, COUNTY HEALTH RANKINGS AND FOCUS GROUPS WITH ELEMENTS OF FORCES OF CHANGE. THE MINI-MAPP PROCESS ALSO HELPED TO IDENTIFY AND VALIDATE PREVIOUSLY DETERMINED COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS THAT ENABLED MARY LANNING TO CREATE AN IMPLEMENTATION PLAN THAT IS IN ALIGNMENT WITH THE SHDHD'S CHIP (COMMUNITY HEALTH IMPROVEMENT PLAN) AS BOTH PLANS WORK TOGETHER TO ADDRESS THE NEEDS IN THE IDENTIFIED COMMUNITY.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: MARY LANNING HEALTHCARE
ExplntnTxt: PART V, SECTION B, LINE 11: THE HOSPITAL IS ADDRESSING THE SIGNIFICANT NEEDS IDENTIFIED IN ITS MOST RECENTLY CONDUCTED CHNA BY: ADOPTING AN IMPLEMENTATION STRATEGY ADDRESSING EACH OF THE COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS IDENTIFIED, EXECUTION OF THE IMPLEMENTATION STRATEGY, PARTICIPATION IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF A COMMUNITY-WIDE PLAN, INCLUSION OF A COMMUNITY BENEFIT SECTION IN OPERATIONAL PLANS, ADOPTION OF A BUDGET FOR PROVISION OF SERVICES THAT ADDRESS THE NEEDS IDENTIFIED IN THE CHNA, PRIORITIZATION OF THE HEALTH NEEDS IN THE COMMUNITY AND PRIORITIZATION OF SERVICES THAT THE HOSPITAL FACILITY WILL UNDERTAKE TO MEET HEALTH NEEDS IN ITS COMMUNITY. MARY LANNING PARTNERED WITH THE SOUTH HEARTLAND DISTRICT HEALTH DEPARTMENT TO COORDINATE OUR IMPLEMENTATION PLAN WITH THEIR COMMUNITY HEALTH IMPROVEMENT PLAN (CHIP). MONTHLY MEETINGS WERE HELD WITH THE HEALTH DEPARTMENT AND OTHER PARTNER ORGANIZATIONS TO DISCUSS PROGRESS AND AVOID DUPLICATION. THE MARY LANNING TEAM ALSO CONTINUED TO UPDATE AND PROVIDE SERVICES IN THE FIVE AREAS OF NEED. HIGHLIGHTS FROM EACH AREA OF NEED INCLUDE THE FOLLOWING: OBESITY: MLH IS COMMITTED TO INCREASING COMMUNICATION WITH THEIR PATIENTS ON OPPORTUNITIES AVAILABLE TO ADDRESS OBESITY; AND INCREASE COMMUNITY AWARENESS OF THE IMPORTANCE OF WELLBEING IN ALL FIVE AREAS: PURPOSE, SOCIAL, FINANCIAL, PHYSICAL AND COMMUNITY; CANCER: MLH IS COMMITTED TO DEVELOPING A WOMEN'S HEALTH PROGRAM, DEVELOPING A PATIENT NAVIGATION SYSTEM AT THE MORRISON CANCER CENTER, PROVIDING AND EDUCATING THE COMMUNITY ON AVAILABLE SCREENING, AND COLLABORATING WITH THE HOME HEALTH DEPARTMENT TO DEVELOP SERVICES FOR WOMEN AND CHILDREN. MENTAL HEALTH: MLH IS COMMITTED TO IMPLEMENTING THE INTEGRATED CARE MODEL; EXPANDING TELE-MENTAL HEALTH; AND EXPANDING MENTAL HEALTH FIRST AID. SUBSTANCE ABUSE: MLH IS COMMITTED TO TRAINING PROVIDERS TO IDENTIFY AND REFER HIGH-RISK PATIENTS. ACCESS TO CARE: MLH IS COMMITTED TO DEVELOPING A STRATEGY TO ENCOURAGE MEDICARE RECIPIENTS TO EXAMINE THEIR PART D OPTIONS ANNUALLY, EXPANDING INTERPRETER SERVICES; EXPANDING TELE-HEALTH TECHNOLOGY; COLLABORATING WITH HOSPITALIST LEADERSHIP TO DEVELOP A FORMAL PALLIATIVE CARE PROGRAM; AND IMPLEMENT A HEALTH LITERACY INITIATIVE AT MLH THROUGH PARTNERSHIP WITH SHDHD.PRIORITIZED NEEDS STAKEHOLDERS IN THE ORIGINAL MAPP PROCESS WERE ASKED TO RANK ALL NEEDS ON A SCALE TO DETERMINE PRIORITY AREAS. THE TOP FOUR RANKED AREAS THROUGH THIS PROCESS WERE: OBESITY, CANCER, SUBSTANCE ABUSE AND MENTAL HEALTH. ACCESS TO CARE WAS ALSO IDENTIFIED PREVIOUSLY THROUGH THE PUBLIC HEALTH SYSTEM ASSESSMENT. THE PROCESS OF THE MINI-MAPP AGAIN IDENTIFIED ALL FIVE AS AN AREA OF NEED AND THESE AREAS WILL CONTINUE TO BE THE PRIORITY FOR MARY LANNING HEALTHCARE. THE OTHER NEEDS THAT WERE IDENTIFIED THROUGH THE ASSESSMENT PROCESS THAT ARE NOT CURRENTLY BEING ADDRESSED INCLUDE: CARDIOVASCULAR, INJURY, ENVIRONMENTAL, DIABETES, COMMUNICABLE DISEASE, REPRODUCTIVE HEALTH AND ORAL HEALTH. IT IS ANTICIPATED THAT SEVERAL AREAS WILL OVERLAP AND ONE ACTIVITY MAY MEET THE STRATEGIC GOAL IN SEVERAL AREAS AND MAY HAVE A POSITIVE IMPACT ON NEEDS THAT ARE IDENTIFIED BUT NOT IN THE TOP FIVE PRIORITY AREAS. FOR EXAMPLE, ADDRESSING NUTRITION UNDER THE PRIORITY AREA OF OBESITY WOULD LOGICALLY HAVE AN IMPACT ON PREVALENCE OF DIABETES AND HEART DISEASE AS WELL AS INCREASING ACCESS TO CARE.

ExplntnTxt: MERCY MEDICAL CENTER CONDUCTED A COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS ASSESSMENT (CHNA) IN ASSOCIATION WITH LONG ISLAND HEALTH COLLABORATIVE (LIHC) MEMBERS. THE LIHC IS A PARTNERSHIP OF LONG ISLAND'S HOSPITALS, COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENTS, HEALTH PROVIDERS, COMMUNITY-BASED SOCIAL AND HUMAN SERVICE ORGANIZATIONS, ACADEMIC INSTITUTIONS, HEALTH PLANS, LOCAL GOVERNMENT, AND THE BUSINESS SECTOR, ALL ENGAGED IN IMPROVING THE HEALTH OF LONG ISLANDERS. THE LIHC IS THE MAIN WORKING GROUP ASSOCIATED WITH CARRYING OUT THE GOALS OF THE LONG ISLAND POPULATION HEALTH IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM. IN 2016, MEMBERS OF LIHC REVIEWED EXTENSIVE DATA SETS SELECTED FROM BOTH PRIMARY AND SECONDARY DATA SOURCES TO IDENTIFY AND CONFIRM PREVENTION AGENDA PRIORITIES FOR THE 2016-2018 COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS ASSESSMENT CYCLE. PRIMARY DATA SOURCES COLLECTED AND ANALYZED INCLUDE THE LONG ISLAND COMMUNITY HEALTH ASSESSMENT SURVEY, QUALITATIVE DATA FROM COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATION SUMMIT EVENTS, AND THE LIHC WELLNESS SURVEY. THE BROAD COMMUNITY WAS ENGAGED IN ASSESSMENT EFFORTS THROUGH THE DISTRIBUTION AND COMPLETION OF THE PREVENTION AGENDA COMMUNITY MEMBER SURVEYS. THIS TOOL WAS DEVELOPED IN COLLABORATION WITH COMMUNITY PARTNERS FROM THE LIHC. DATA FROM THIS SURVEY WERE COLLECTED AUGUST 1, 2015 THROUGH APRIL 30, 2016 THROUGH DISTRIBUTION AND PROMOTION OF THIS SURVEY THROUGHOUT A WIDE RANGE OF SOCIAL SERVICE LOCATIONS, INCLUDING MERCY MEDICAL CENTER, DOCTORS OFFICES, HEALTH DEPARTMENTS, LIBRARIES, SCHOOLS, INSURANCE ENROLLMENT SITES AND COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATIONS. THIS INCLUDES THE MEDICALLY UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES OF VALLEY STREAM, HEMPSTEAD, ROOSEVELT, FREEPORT, AND UNIONDALE. MERCY MEDICAL CENTER PROMOTES THE SURVEY THROUGH SOCIAL MEDIA LINKS, ON ITS WEBSITE, AND BY DISTRIBUTING SURVEYS AT HEALTH FAIRS AND OTHER CONSUMER-ORIENTED EVENTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: PART V, SECTION B, LINE 11
ExplntnTxt: MERCY MEDICAL CENTER AND LIHC COMMUNITY PARTNERS SELECTED CHRONIC DISEASE AS THE PRIORITY AREA WITH A FOCUS ON (1) OBESITY AND (2) PREVENTIVE CARE AND MANAGEMENT FOR THE 2016-2018 CYCLE. MENTAL HEALTH WILL BE HIGHLIGHTED WITHIN ALL INTERVENTION STRATEGIES. PRIORITY 1: OBESITY MERCY MEDICAL CENTER IS WORKING TO REDUCE OBESITY IN ADULTS THROUGH COMMUNITY-BASED AWARENESS INITIATIVES SUCH AS FREE COMMUNITY LECTURES AND BMI SCREENINGS. IN 2016, MERCYS DIABETES EDUCATOR DELIVERED 6 NUTRITION AND WEIGHT LOSS SESSIONS TO 40 PEOPLE FROM THE SURROUNDING AREA. MERCY MEDICAL CENTER OFFERS A BARIATRIC CLINIC FOR UNDERSERVED INDIVIDUALS WHO ARE OBESE AND AT-RISK FOR DEVELOPING RELATED HEALTH ISSUES. IN 2016, THE NY BARIATRIC GROUP DELIVERED MORE THAN 40 WEIGHT LOSS SESSIONS TO APPROXIMATELY 400 PATIENTS. MERCY MEDICAL CENTER PROMOTES THE LONG ISLAND HEALTH COLLABORATIVES (LIHC) ARE YOU READY FEET WALKING PROGRAM BY DISTRIBUTING PROMOTIONAL MATERIAL AT COMMUNITY EVENTS AND THROUGH SOCIAL MEDIA. THIS MATERIAL IS ALSO AVAILABLE IN THE HOSPITAL AND IS SHARED WITH CHS-AFFILIATED PHYSICIANS AND MID-LEVEL PRACTITIONERS TO ENCOURAGE MORE PEOPLE TO WALK AND CHOOSE A HEALTHIER LIFESTYLE. MERCY MEDICAL CENTER PARTICIPATES IN THE AMERICAN HEART ASSOCIATION HEART WALK, THE LONG ISLAND MARCUM WORKPLACE CHALLENGE - A 3.5-MILE RUN-WALK FOR CHARITY - AND THE AMERICAN CANCER SOCIETYS MAKING STRIDES AGAINST BREAST CANCER WALK. THESE EVENTS ENCOURAGE WALKING FOR PHYSICAL ACTIVITY AND GOOD HEALTH FOR EMPLOYEES AND THE COMMUNITY. EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS ARE OFFERED AT EACH EVENT TO PARTICIPANTS. PRIORITY 2: PREVENTIVE CARE AND MANAGEMENT MERCY MEDICAL CENTER IS WORKING TO INCREASE ACCESS TO AND KNOWLEDGE OF PREVENTIVE CARE FOR HEART DISEASE AND DIABETES IN BOTH CLINICAL AND COMMUNITY SETTINGS. MERCY PARTICIPATES IN COMMUNITY PROGRAMS DESIGNED TO REACH PEOPLE OUTSIDE TRADITIONAL HEALTH CARE SETTINGS IN MEDICALLY-UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. MERCY PROVIDED DIABETES INFORMATION PACKAGES IN ENGLISH AND SPANISH TO MORE THAN 70 PEOPLE AT THE MARCH 1, 2016, "LIGHTING OF THE DOME" COMMUNITY EVENT IN HEMPSTEAD. IN 2016, MERCY MEDICAL CENTER HOSTED A WELLNESS DAY AND PROVIDED 25 FREE BLOOD PRESSURE SCREENINGS WITH HEART HEALTH AND DIABETES EDUCATION FOR 90 INDIVIDUALS, INCLUDING THOSE FROM THE UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES OF HEMPSTEAD, ROOSEVELT, FREEPORT AND UNIONDALE. MERCY MEDICAL CENTER PROVIDED FREE SCREENINGS FOR BLOOD PRESSURE AND BMI WITHIN SELECT UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. IN 2016, BLOOD PRESSURE SCREENINGS AND FREE HEALTH EDUCATION MATERIAL WAS PROVIDED TO 60 INDIVIDUALS AT THE ROCKVILLE CENTRE COMMUNITY EAT SHOP AND ROCK FAIR AND AT FIDELIS CARES BACK-TO-SCHOOL HEALTH FAIR IN HEMPSTEAD. MERCYS FREE SPEAKERS BUREAU PROVIDED FREE EDUCATION TO THE COMMUNITY ON VARIOUS HEALTH AND WELLNESS PROGRAMS AND PREVENTIVE CARE AND MANAGEMENT. NINE OSTOMY SUPPORT GROUP SESSIONS FOR 90 PEOPLE FROM THE SURROUNDING MERCY CATCHMENT AREA WERE HELD. A SPEAKER WAS AT EACH SESSION, DELIVERING HEALTH INFORMATION ON A VARIETY OF TOPICS. NINE LOSS OF A SPOUSE/PARTNER SUPPORT GROUP SESSIONS AND NINE GENERAL BEREAVEMENT SUPPORT GROUP SESSIONS WERE HELD AT MERCY, IN PARTNERSHIP WITH GOOD SHEPHERD HOSPICE. MERCY PROMOTES CULTURALLY RELEVANT CHRONIC DISEASE SELF-MANAGEMENT EDUCATION THROUGH FREE MONTHLY DIABETES EDUCATION SESSIONS. IN 2016, 12 FREE DIABETES EDUCATION SESSIONS WERE DELIVERED TO INDIVIDUALS FROM SURROUNDING UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES. MERCY OFFERED 2 FREE WOUND CARE SCREENINGS AT THE HOSPITAL WITH A TOTAL OF 33 ATTENDEES. IN AUGUST 2016, IN COLLABORATION WITH MOLLOY COLLEGE, MERCY MEDICAL CENTER PROVIDED FREE CARDIAC SCREENING TO SIX MOLLOY COLLEGE ATHLETES. ONE STUDENT WAS IDENTIFIED WITH A MINOR HEART PROBLEM AND WAS REFERRED TO A PHYSICIAN FOR FOLLOW-UP. THE PROGRAM WAS A SUCCESS, AND MERCY PLANS TO DELIVER ANOTHER SCREENING IN 2017. MERCY MEDICAL CENTER STAFF VOLUNTEER AT CHS HEALTHY SUNDAYS COMMUNITY OUTREACH EVENTS HELD IN CHURCHES IN UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES, OFFERING FREE HEALTH SCREENINGS AND FREE EDUCATIONAL MATERIALS ON OBESITY, HEART HEALTH, AND DIABETES. IN 2016, STAFF FROM MERCY MEDICAL CENTER PROVIDED SCREENINGS AT 3 HEALTHY SUNDAY EVENTS WITH 138 PARTICIPANTS IN THE UNDERSERVED COMMUNITIES OF UNIONDALE AND LONG BEACH. BLOOD PRESSURE SCREENINGS WERE PROVIDED TO 138 INDIVIDUALS, BMI SCREENINGS PROVIDED TO 46, AND 69 RECEIVED FLU VACCINATIONS. THERE WERE FOUR REFERRALS FOR FREE FOLLOW-UP CARE. MERCY MEDICAL CENTER AND ST. FRANCIS HOSPITAL PARTNERED TO DONATE 50 AUTOMATED EXTERNAL DEFIBRILLATORS (AEDS), VALUED AT $1,500 EACH, TO THE TOWN OF HEMPSTEAD FOR PLACEMENT AT PARKS, POOLS, BEACHES, AND SENIOR CENTERS. DEFIBRILLATORS ARE OFTEN UTILIZED BY POLICE, FIRE, AND OTHER EMERGENCY PERSONNEL DUE TO THEIR PROVEN ABILITY TO SAVE LIVES. THE DEVICES, PRODUCED BY CARDIAC SCIENCE CORPORATION, COME WITH STEP-BY-STEP INSTRUCTIONS, SO IN THE EVENT OF AN EXTREME EMERGENCY, ANYONE CAN QUICKLY LEARN THE STEPS TO HELP SOMEONE IN CARDIAC ARREST. THE DEVICES INCLUDE BILINGUAL (SPANISH/ENGLISH) INSTRUCTIONS, MAKING THEM ACCESSIBLE TO A BROAD POPULATION. MERCY OFFERED A FREE, SEVEN-WEEK STEPPING ON PROGRAM WHICH IS AN EVIDENCE BASED FALL PREVENTION PROGRAM DESIGNED TO REDUCE FALLS AND BUILD CONFIDENCE IN OLDER ADULTS. ONE CLASS WAS HELD FROM SEPTEMBER 27, 2016 THROUGH NOVEMBER 8, 2016 AND HAD 15 PARTICIPANTS. PRIORITY 3: MENTAL HEALTH MERCY MEDICAL CENTER IS PARTICIPATING IN DSRIP PROJECT 2.B.II PROJECT, CO LOCATING PRIMARY CARE ADJACENT TO THE EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT. THE PRIMARY CARE PRACTICE WILL BE HEADED BY JACQUELINE DELMONT, MD, AND IS USING LEASED SPACE FROM MERCY. IN ADDITION, THE PRIMARY CARE SPACE WILL BE USED FOR OTHER DSRIP PROJECTS. AS PART OF 3.A.I - THE INTEGRATION OF PRIMARY CARE AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH - THE SITE WILL BE PARTICIPATING IN MODEL 1 AND WILL EMBED A LICENSED MASTER SOCIAL WORKER. MERCY MEDICAL CENTERS BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES PROVIDES A BIMONTHLY FAMILY SUPPORT GROUP FOR THE COMMUNITY AND CAREGIVERS OF THE CLINICS PATIENTS. THE FAMILY SUPPORT GROUP IS A SUPPORTIVE VEHICLE FOR CAREGIVERS. MERCY MEDICAL CENTERS DIRECTOR OF BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES IS A MEMBER OF NASSAU COUNTYS HEROIN TASKFORCE. THIS ADVOCACY ACTIVITY ENGENDERED VALUED RELATIONSHIPS WITH KEY COUNTY LEADERSHIP ON THE LOCAL OPIOID CRISIS. MERCY MEDICAL CENTERS BEHAVIORAL HEALTH SERVICES STAFF PROVIDED THE FOLLOWING NINE FREE MENTAL HEALTH PRESENTATIONS COVERING A VARIETY OF TOPICS. 8/17/16: A BEHAVIORAL HEALTH PRESENTATION FOR THE DIABETES SUPPORT GROUP WAS HELD AT MERCY WITH 25 ATTENDEES. 9/17/16: A BEHAVIORAL HEALTH INFORMATION TABLE WAS INCLUDED IN THE MERCY HEALTH FAIR, WHICH HAD 125 ATTENDEES. 10/6/16: A MANAGING STRESS PRESENTATION WAS HELD AT THE MALVERNE PUBLIC LIBRARY WITH SIX ATTENDEES. 12/16/16: BEHAVIOR HEALTH CLINICIANS MET WITH REPRESENTATIVES FROM ST. VINCENT DE PAUL (SVDP) OF LONG ISLAND TO DISCUSS A PARTNERSHIP WHERE MERCYS BEHAVIORAL HEALTH STAFF WOULD EVALUATE SVDP CLIENTS WHO ARE SCHEDULED TO LEAVE THEIR TRANSITIONAL HOUSING PROGRAMS IN ROOSEVELT FOR A STABLE AND BUDGET FRIENDLY LIVING ARRANGEMENT. THE FREE CHS MENTAL HEALTH AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE SERVICES GUIDE IS AVAILABLE THROUGHOUT THE HOSPITAL AND AT ALL COMMUNITY OUTREACH EVENTS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Part V, Section B, Question 5
ExplntnTxt: AS PART OF THE CHNA PROCESS, THE ORGANIZATION CONTRACTED WITH SETON HALL UNIVERSITY'S SETON CENTER FOR COMMUNITY AND POPULATION HEALTH ("SCCPH") TO CONDUCT A RIGOROUS COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS ASSESSMENT ("CHNA") PROCESS THAT PRODUCED AN ACCURATE AND REPRESENTATIVE SNAPSHOT FOR PRIMARY SERVICE AREAS AND REFLECTED THE VOICE OF THE COMMUNITY. ADDITIONALLY, SCCPH COLLABORATED WITH THE HEALTHY COMMUNITIES INSTITUTE ("HCI") TO DEVELOPE A WEB-BASED PLATFORM, WHICH INCLUDED 132 HEALTH AND QUALITY OF LIFE INDICATORS FOR ANY COMMUNITY OR COUNTY. PRIMARY DATA COLLECTION ------------------------------------------- IN AN EFFORT TO SOLICIT INPUT FROM KEY INFORMANTS, THOSE INDIVIDUALS WHO HAVE A BROAD INTEREST IN THE HEALTH OF THE COMMUNITY, THE ORGANIZATION COMPLETED A COMPREHENSIVE REVIEW OF BACKGROUND MATERIALS, INCLUDING BUT NOT LIMITED TO PAST REPORTS, EVALUATIONS, DATA, AND STRATEGIC IMPLEMENTATION OUTCOMES. THE ORGANIZATION AND SCCPH DEVELOPED A DETAILED PLAN FOR PRIMARY DATA COLLECTION. THIS ACTIVITY INVOLVED OUTREACH AND CONSULTATION WITH COMMUNITY REPRESENTATIVES, MUNICIPAL ORGANIZATIONS, HEALTH AGENCIES, AND OTHER INTERESTED STAKEHOLDERS. THIS PLAN ENSURED ADEQUATE REPRESENTATION AND ENGAGEMENT. AS PART OF THE CHNA PROCESS, THE ORGANIZATION COMPLETED A PRIMARY DATA STRATEGY, WHICH INCLUDED: - A PERSONALIZED/TAILORED CHNA QUESTIONNAIRE; - COMMUNITY-BASED FOCUS GROUPS; AND - KEY INFORMANT INTERVIEWS. JFK CHNA QUESTIONNAIRE/SURVEY ----------------------------------------------------- BASED ON BEST PRACTICE MODELS IDENTIFIED BY THE ASSOCIATION FOR COMMUNITY HEALTH IMPROVEMENTS COMMUNITY HEALTH ASSESSMENT TOOLKIT, SCCPH DEVELOPED A 23 ITEM CHNA SURVEY FOR THE ORGANIZATION. SURVEY ITEMS INCLUDED BASIC POPULATION PROFILE QUESTIONS, HEALTH STATUS UPDATES, ASSESSMENT OF COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS AND CHALLENGES, AND A PRIORITIZATION OF POTENTIAL COMMUNITY HEALTH ISSUES. RESPONDENTS WERE ALSO GIVEN SEVERAL OPPORTUNITIES TO SHARE THEIR PERSPECTIVES AND PRIMARY HEALTH CONCERNS. THE SURVEYS WERE DISTRIBUTED DURING THE SUMMER OF 2016 VIA EMAIL AND WEB LINKS. PAPER COPIES WERE ALSO DISTRIBUTED WITHIN THE FOLLOWING REPRESENTATIVE SERVICE AREA LOCATIONS: - EDISON SENIOR SERVICES; - LINCOLN TECHNICAL INSTITUTE ISELIN CAMPUS (LPN NURSING STUDENTS); - PLAINFIELD HEALTH CONNECTIONS PROGRAM (RUN THROUGH JFK HEALTH); - JFK HEALTH FAMILY MEDICINE CENTER; - JFK RADIATION ONCOLOGY DEPARTMENT; - JFK MEDICAL CENTER OUTPATIENT WAITING ROOM; AND - JFK HEALTH VOLUNTEER SERVICES. THE ORGANIZATION ADVERTISED THE SURVEY THROUGH THE WEBSITE, PRINTED MEDIA (NEWSLETTERS) AND ACCESSIBILITY VIA AN E-SURVEY. THE JFK CHNA QUESTIONNAIRES WERE MADE AVAILABLE IN ENGLISH, SPANISH, MANDARIN AND GUJARATI. ALL RESPONSES WERE KEPT STRICTLY CONFIDENTIAL. COMMUNITY-BASED FOCUS GROUPS ------------------------------------------------------- ON BEHALF OF THE ORGANIZATION, SCCPH CONDUCTED THREE TARGETED FOCUS GROUPS DURING THE SUMMER OF 2016 TO OBTAIN COMMENTS AND SUGGESTIONS FROM INTERESTED AND KNOWLEDGEABLE COMMUNITY OFFICIALS AND REPRESENTATIVES. THE FIRST FOCUS GROUP INCLUDED MUNICIPAL REPRESENTATIVES FROM THE ORGANIZATIONS PRIMARY SERVICE AREA INCLUDING PUBLIC HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENTAL DIRECTORS AND OTHER LOCAL AND COUNTY REPRESENTATIVES.THESE REPRESENTATIVES INCLUDED PARTICIPANTS FROM THE FOLLOWING STAKEHOLDER GROUPS: - EDISON SENIOR SERVICES; - EDISON HEALTH DEPARTMENT; - MIDDLESEX COUNTY OFFICE OF PLANNING; - BOROUGH OF METUCHEN BUSINESS ADMINISTRATOR; - SOUTH PLAINFIELD MAYORS WELLNESS COMMITTEE; - MIDDLESEX COUNTY REGIONAL CHRONIC DISEASE COORDINATOR; - MIDDLESEX COUNTY HEALTH EDUCATORS; AND - MIDDLESEX COUNTY INTERNS. THE SECOND FOCUS GROUP ENGAGED INTERESTED INDIVIDUALS FROM VARIOUS LOCAL COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS INCLUDING: - EDISON GREENWAYS GROUP INC; - YMCA OF METUCHEN; - YMCA OF EDISON; AND - YMCA OF WOODBRIDGE. THE THIRD FOCUS GROUP CONSISTED OF JFKMC AND JRI EMPLOYEES WHO WERE INVITED TO ATTEND AND CONTRIBUTE THEIR PERSPECTIVES ON THE COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS OF THEIR PATIENTS AND CONSUMERS. THESE EMPLOYEES REPRESENTED INPUT FROM THE FOLLOWING HOSPITAL DEPARTMENTS: - VOLUNTEER SERVICES; - QUALITY & ACCREDITATION; - DIAGNOSTIC IMAGING; - NEUROSCIENCE; - ENDOCRINOLOGY; - Critical Care Unit; - JFK @ HOME; - REHABILITATION; - CENTER FOR BEHAVIORAL HEALTH; - FITNESS; - ADMITTING; - NUCLEAR MEDICINE; - MATERIALS MANAGEMENT; - ACCOUNTS PAYABLE; - BARIATRIC SURGERY; - NURSING; - HEALTH INFORMATION SERVICES; - MRI CENTER; - NURSING ADMINISTRATION; - HOSPITALITY SERVICES; - DIAGNOSTIC IMAGINING; - CASE MANAGEMENT; - SOCIAL WORK; AND - BREAST SURGERY ASSOCIATES. A FINAL FOCUS GROUP WAS CONDUCTED WITH REPRESENTATIVES FROM THE PLAINFIELD HEALTH COALITION. INVITATION LETTERS WERE SENT TO ALL DESIGNATED COMMUNITY PARTICIPANTS. ALL FOCUS GROUPS WERE HELD AT THE ORGANIZATIONS HEADQUARTERS IN EDISON, NEW JERSEY EXCEPT FOR THE PLAINFIELD FOCUS GROUP SESSION. EACH FOCUS GROUP FOLLOWED A PRE-SET LIST OF QUESTIONS IN ORDER TO ENSURE CONSISTENCY ACROSS EACH FOCUS GROUP SESSION. FOCUS GROUPS WERE RECORDED AND TRANSCRIBED. MAJOR THEMES WERE IDENTIFIED AND COLLATED. FINDINGS ARE PRESENTED BY GROUP. FOCUS GROUP MEMBERS INTRODUCED THEMSELVES AND THEN RESPONDED TO THESE CORE SET OF QUESTIONS. THESE INCLUDED: - HOW WELL DO JFKMC AND JRI SERVE THE COMMUNITY? ARE THERE ANY WEAKNESSES? - ARE THERE COMMUNITY HEALTH SERVICES THAT JFK SHOULD CONTINUE TO EXPAND? - ARE THERE OPPORTUNITIES FOR THE JFKMC AND JRI TO BETTER MEET THE COMMUNITYS HEALTH NEEDS? EACH FOCUS GROUP LASTED A MINIMUM OF ONE AND ONE HALF HOURS. SCCPH FACILITATORS ENCOURAGED PARTICIPANTS TO EXPAND ON COMMENTS AND PROPOSED SOLUTIONS. ALL PARTICIPANTS WERE ENGAGED AND PROVIDED CLEAR RECOMMENDATIONS BASED ON THEIR PERCEPTIONS OF COMMUNITY HEALTHCARE PROBLEMS. IN ADDITION TO THE TAPED RECORDING, A JFK-MHA STUDENT INTERN TOOK NOTES AND A FLIPCHART WAS USED TO HELP COLLATE IDEAS AND SOLUTIONS. ALL FOCUS GROUP MEMBERS WERE ENCOURAGED TO COMPLETE THE JFKMC AND JRI QUESTIONNAIRE IF THEY HAD NOT ALREADY DONE SO. WHILE THE DISCUSSION FOCUSED ON MANY ISSUES, SEVERAL THEMES WERE APPARENT ACROSS THE DIFFERENT GROUPS. ALL PARTICIPATING STAKEHOLDERS OFFERED OPINIONS AND CONTEXT FOR COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS. THE COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDER GROUP IDENTIFIED SEVERAL ISSUES THAT ARE BEING ADDRESSED BY THE ORGANIZATION. KEY INFORMANT INTERVIEWS -------------------------------------------- THE ORGANIZATION WORKED WITH SCCPH TO COMPLETE A PERSONAL INTERVIEW WITH THE JFKMC AND JRI COMMUNITY OUTREACH COORDINATOR. OTHER KEY INFORMANTS WERE IDENTIFIED USING RECOMMENDATIONS FROM JFKMC AND JRI SENIOR STAFF AND COMMUNITY LEADERS. THESE ACTIVITIES ENSURED THAT ALL DATA WERE GROUNDED IN THE REALITIES OF THE COMMUNITIES THAT JFKMC AND JRI SERVES. THE KEY INFORMANTS INCLUDED A LOCAL PUBLIC HEALTH OFFICER, AN EXECUTIVE MANAGER FROM JOHNSON REHABILITATION INSTITUTE AND A JFKMC AND JRI REPRESENTATIVE. TOGETHER, THEIR INPUT HELPED PROVIDE ADDITIONAL DETAIL AND CONTEXT FOR UNDERSTANDING THE COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS AND THEIR RELATIONSHIP TO JFKMC AND JRI. KEY INFORMANTS PROVIDED SIGNIFICANT DETAIL ON PREVIOUSLY INDICATED AREAS OF COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS. DETAILS INCLUDED A CLARIFICATION OF RISK FACTORS, ISSUES RELATED TO CONTINUITY AND DELIVERY OF CARE AND A DESCRIPTION OF THE MOST VULNERABLE POPULATIONS AND THE BARRIERS THEY ENCOUNTER. THE KEY INFORMANTS PROVIDE SEVERAL RELEVANT RECOMMENDATIONS ALONG WITH PROPOSED ACTIVITIES TO SUPPORT POSITIVE OUTCOMES. ALL KEY INFORMANTS HIGHLIGHTED THE NEED FOR TRUE PARTNERSHIP AND ENGAGEMENT WITH COMMUNITY LEADERS AND HEALTH ORGANIZATIONS. IN ADDITION, REPRESENTATIVES ATTENDED SEVERAL CENTRAL NEW JERSEY COALITION MEETINGS AND OTHER PLANNING EVENTS TO OBTAIN CONTEXTUAL EVIDENCE. THESE EVENTS INCLUDED THE FOLLOWING: - HANDS OF HOPE; - EDISON FAMILY DAY; - METUCHEN LIBRARY; - THE BAPS TEMPLE HEALTH FAIR; - MIDDLESEX COUNTY FAITH HEALTH INITIATIVE CONFERENCE; - COMMUNITY HEALTH CONSORTIUM FOR CENTRAL JERSEY; AND - MIDDLESEX COUNTY WELLNESS COUNCIL. CONCLUSION -------------------- USING THE FINDINGS FROM THE JFK-CHNA SURVEY QUESTIONNAIRE, FOCUS GROUPS AND KEY INFORMANT INTERVIEWS PROVIDED A CLEAR REPRESENTATION OF THE COMMUNITYS VOICE AND THEIR PERCEPTION OF CURRENT HEALTH NEEDS AND HEALTH STATUS. THESE METHODS PROVIDED SIGNIFICANT COMMUNITY INPUT FOR THE CHNA PROCESS.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Part V, Section B, Questions 6A & 6B
ExplntnTxt: THE COMMUNITY HOSPITAL GROUP, INC. IS AN INTERNAL REVENUE CODE 501(C)(3) TAX-EXEMPT ORGANIZATION WHICH OPERATES TWO HOSPITAL FACILITIES, (1) ANTHONY M. YELENCSICS COMMUNITY HOSPITAL, AN ACUTE CARE HOSPITAL FACILITY AND (2) JFK JOHNSON REHABILITATION INSTITUTE (FORMERLY KNOWN AS ROBERT WOOD JOHNSON, JR. REHABILITATION INSTITUTE), A REHABILITATION FACILITY. THE TWO HOSPITAL FACILITIES ARE COLLECTIVELY REFERRED TO AS "JFK MEDICAL CENTER". THESE HOSPITAL FACILITIES ARE BOTH LOCATED AT 65 JAMES STREET EDISON, NJ 08820. THE TWO HOSPITAL FACILITIES HAVE THE SAME PRIMARY SERVICE AREA AND DEFINE THEIR COMMUNITIES TO BE THE SAME, AS REQUIRED BY IRC 501(R)(3). GIVEN THESE FACTS AND CIRCUMSTANCES, THE HOSPITAL FACILITIES COLLABORATED TO FILE A JOINT CHNA FOR THE YEAR ENDED DECEMBER 31, 2016. IN ADDITION, THE HOSPITAL FACILITIES WORKED IN COLLABORATION WITH THE SETON CENTER FOR COMMUNITY AND POPULATION HEALTH AND THE HEALTHY COMMUNITIES INSTITUTE TO COMPLETE ITS 2016 CHNA. THE SETON CENTER FOR COMMUNITY AND POPULATION HEALTH WAS ESTABLISHED IN 2004 AS AN ACADEMIC RESOURCE FOR COLLABORATION, LEARNING, AND RESEARCH TO ENHANCE THE QUALITY OF LIFE FOR INDIVIDUALS AND COMMUNITIES IN NEED. THE ORGANIZATION IS LOCATED IN THE DEPARTMENT OF INTERPROFESSIONAL HEALTH SCIENCES AND HEALTH ADMINISTRATION IN THE SCHOOL OF HEALTH AND MEDICAL SCIENCES WITHIN SETON HALL UNIVERSITY. SINCE ITS INCEPTION THE ORGANIZATION HAS PARTNERED WITH MULTIPLE COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS ON GRANTS INVOLVING MHA STUDENTS FROM SETON HALL UNIVERSITY. THE HEALTHY COMMUNITIES INSTITUTE ("HCI") OFFERS A WEB-BASED DASHBOARD SYSTEM THAT ALLOWS DATA TO BE EASILY VISUALIZED AND COMPREHENDED BY ITS USERS. THE WEB PORTAL ALLOWS COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS TO UNDERSTAND THE VARIETY OF DATA, AND TO BE ABLE TO TAKE CONCRETE ACTION AND IMPROVE TARGET AREAS OF INTEREST. HCI HAS OVER 100 IMPLEMENTATIONS OF ITS DASHBOARD FOR CLIENTS IN 35+ STATES. THE HCI MISSION IS TO IMPROVE THE HEALTH, ENVIRONMENTAL SUSTAINABILITY, AND ECONOMIC VITALITY OF CITIES, COUNTIES, AND COMMUNITIES WORLDWIDE. THE COMPANY IS ROOTED IN WORK STARTED IN 2002 IN CONCERT WITH THE HEALTHY CITIES MOVEMENT AT THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT BERKELEY. HCI STAFF ARE EXPERTS IN MANAGING AND PRESENTING DATA WITH EXTENSIVE EXPERIENCE IN DATA VISUALIZATION AND DATA MAPPING. HCI HAS RECENTLY BECOME PART OF THE XEROX COMPANY.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Part V, Section B, Question 11
ExplntnTxt: THE 2016 CHNA IDENTIFIED 29 HEALTH NEEDS IN THE ORGANIZATIONS PRIMARY SERVICE AREA. THE FINAL PRIORITIZATION PROCESS WAS BASED ON RECOGNIZING THE IMPORTANT ROLE OF JFKS NOT-FOR-PROFIT MISSION AND THE ABILITY TO IMPACT COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS. ALL 29 OF THE HEALTH NEEDS IDENTIFIED BY THE COMMUNITY ARE CATEGORIZED AND PRIORITIZED BY THE BELOW MISSION RATING CRITERIA: (A) CORE RELATIONSHIP TO THE HOSPITALS MISSION; (B) CONTINUATION OF THE PRIORITIES IDENTIFIED IN ITS 2013 CHNA; (C) SIGNIFICANT DISPARITIES WITH BENCHMARK COMPARISONS; (D) TOP HEALTH CONCERNS IDENTIFIED IN THE JFKMC AND JRI CHNA QUESTIONNAIRE FINDINGS; AND (E) RELEVANCE FOR BOTH JFKMC AND JRI POPULATIONS. PRIORITIZATION OF COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS USING MISSION CRITERIA ----------------------------------------------------------------- THE FINAL HEALTH NEEDS PRIORITIZATION STEP INVOLVED ADDITIONAL JFK STRATEGIC CRITERIA: (A) RELATIONSHIP TO EXISTING PROGRAMS; (B) THE ABILITY TO MAKE AN IMPACT WITHIN A REASONABLE TIME FRAME; (C) THE FINANCIAL AND HUMAN RESOURCES REQUIRED; AND (D) WHETHER THERE WOULD BE A MEASURABLE OUTCOME TO GAUGE IMPROVEMENT. THE PROCESS ALSO INCLUDED A REVIEW OF OTHER COMMUNITY RESOURCES THAT MIGHT BE CURRENTLY PROVIDING SIMILAR SERVICES OR ARE BETTER SUITED TO PROVIDE SERVICES TO MEET THE COMMUNITYS NEEDS. THESE CRITERIA WERE USED TO SELECT THE TOP COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS PRIORITIES THAT ALIGN THE ORGANIZATIONS COMMITMENT TO THE COMMUNITY. THE JFK CHNA POPULATION HEALTH MATRIX SHOWS THE FINAL COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS PRIORITY AREAS PLACED UNDER THE THREE POPULATION HEALTH AREAS OF FOCUS. THIS ANALYSIS PERMITTED THE ORGANIZATION TO REVIEW ANY ADDITIONAL NEEDS AND IDENTIFY ANY RESOURCES THAT WOULD BE REQUIRED TO ADDRESS ISSUES THAT ARE OUTSIDE OF JFKMC AND JRIS MISSION. POPULATION HEALTH FOCUS #1: HEALTH PROMOTION AND WELLNESS FOR ALL POPULATIONS ========================================================================= THE GOAL OF THIS FOCUS IS TO IMPROVE ACCESS TO PRIMARY CARE AND DELIVER PREVENTIVE CARE OPPORTUNITIES FOR ALL JFK SERVICE AREA POPULATIONS BY HIGHLIGHTING HEALTH PROMOTION AND WELLNESS INITIATIVES. COMMUNITY OUTREACH/AWARENESS/PHYSICIAN AVAILABILITY ----------------------------------------------------------------------- JFK MEDICAL CENTER FEATURES A ROBUST COMMUNITY OUTREACH PROGRAM, WITH A DEDICATED PART-TIME COORDINATOR AND STAFFED BY PAID CLINICIANS AND VOLUNTEERS. JFK PROVIDES WELLNESS SEMINARS AT THE JFK CAMPUS. IN ADDITION, JFK STAFF MEMBERS PARTICIPATE IN COMMUNITY HEALTH FAIRS THAT ARE HELD YEAR-ROUND AND ARE HOSTED BY COMMUNITY ORGANIZATIONS, SUCH AS LOCAL CHURCHES AND SENIOR CITIZEN CENTERS. JFK/JRI PARTICIPATES IN DOZENS OF COMMUNITY EVENTS EACH YEAR, AS WELL AS SUPPORT GROUPS, EDUCATIONAL SEMINARS AND OTHER WELLNESS EVENTS. HOWEVER, ITS 2016 CHNA FOUND THAT THE COMMUNITY IS UNDER-AWARE OF THESE ACTIVITIES AND HOW TO ACCESS THEM. GOALS: (1) CONTINUE TO MAINTAIN THE JFK COMMUNITY OUTREACH PROGRAM. IN 2016, JFK ASSESSED THE FREQUENCY AND LOCATION OF WELLNESS EVENTS. IN 2017-2018, JFK WILL SEEK TO INCREASE THE FREQUENCY OF WELLNESS EVENTS BY TEN PERCENT. (2) JFK WILL ACTIVELY PROMOTE WELLNESS EVENTS IN ITS MONTHLY EMPLOYEE NEWSLETTER "SPOTLIGHT" TO PUBLICIZE COMMUNITY OUTREACH AND WELLNESS RELATED ACTIVITIES TO INTERNAL AUDIENCES. (3) JFK WILL INCLUDE COMMUNITY OUTREACH AND WELLNESS RELATED EVENTS IN ITS PATIENT AND COMMUNITY E-NEWSLETTER TO HIGHLIGHT EVENTS THAT JFK HAS IN THE COMMUNITY TO EXTERNAL AUDIENCES. PHYSICAL ACTIVITY/WEIGHT CONTROL ---------------------------------------------------------------------- JFK SPONSORS SEVERAL COMMUNITY 5K RUNS AND OPERATES A FITNESS CENTER AT 70 JAMES STREET IN EDISON. THE JFK FOR LIFE WEIGHT LOSS PROGRAM FEATURES FITNESS, DIET AND SURGICAL WEIGHT LOSS SERVICES. THE ORGANIZATION ALSO OFFERS AN EMPLOYEE WELLNESS PROGRAM THAT INCENTIVIZES THOUSANDS OF EMPLOYEE COMMUNITY MEMBERS TO LOSE WEIGHT AND ADOPT HEALTHY BEHAVIORS. GOALS: (1) IMPROVE COMMUNITY PARTICIPATION IN JFK SPONSORED FITNESS AND WELLNESS PROGRAMS - 2017: ASSESS COMMUNITY PARTICIPATION IN 5K RUNS, FITNESS CENTER AND JFK FOR LIFE WEIGHT LOSS PROGRAM AND DEVELOP PLANS TO IMPROVE PARTICIPATION BY FIVE PERCENT BY 2019. - 2018: IMPROVE COMMUNITY PARTICIPATION IN 5K RUNS, FITNESS CENTER AND JFK FOR LIFE WEIGHT LOSS PROGRAM BY TWO PERCENT OVER BASE YEAR. - 2019: IMPROVE COMMUNITY PARTICIPATION IN 5K RUNS, FITNESS CENTER AND JFK FOR LIFE WEIGHT LOSS PROGRAM BY FIVE PERCENT OVER BASE YEAR. (2) IMPROVE EMPLOYEE AND FAMILY PARTICIPATION IN EMPLOYEE WELLNESS PROGRAM - 2017: ASSESS EMPLOYEE AND FAMILY PARTICIPATION IN EMPLOYEE WELLNESS PROGRAMS AND DEVELOP PLANS TO IMPROVE OUTCOMES BY FIVE PERCENT BY 2019. - 2018: IMPROVE EMPLOYEE AND FAMILY PARTICIPATION IN EMPLOYEE WELLNESS PROGRAMS AND DEVELOP PLANS TO IMPROVE OUTCOMES BY TWO PERCENT OVER BASE YEAR. - 2019: IMPROVE EMPLOYEE AND FAMILY PARTICIPATION IN EMPLOYEE WELLNESS PROGRAMS AND DEVELOP PLANS TO IMPROVE OUTCOMES BY FIVE PERCENT OVER BASE YEAR. POPULATION HEALTH FOCUS #2: DISEASE MANAGEMENT FOR ALL POPULATIONS ===================================================================== THE GOAL OF THIS FOCUS IS TO IMPLEMENT TARGETED INITIATIVES FOR AT-RISK POPULATIONS THAT REFLECT A STRATEGY OF "RIGHT CARE, RIGHT PLACE, RIGHT TIME" DIABETES --------------- JFK MEDICAL CENTER IS WORKING TO IMPROVE HEALTH FOR PATIENTS WITH DIABETES THROUGH PROGRAMS SUCH AS THE JFK MEDICARE ACCOUNTABLE CARE ORGANIZATION ("ACO"), JFK DIABETES CENTER, FAMILY PRACTICE, ETC. THE JFK ACO HAS PROVIDED A PLATFORM FOR THE HOSPITAL TO WORK WITH PARTICIPATING PHYSICIANS AND TRACK THE IMPACT THAT THESE PROGRAMS HAVE HAD IN THE COMMUNITY. THE ACO TRACKS ALL DIABETIC PATIENTS ENSURING LAB WORK AND EYE EXAMS ARE PERFORMED YEARLY AS REQUIRED. PROCESSES WERE PUT IN PLACE TO ENSURE THAT THE PRIMARY CARE PHYSICIANS RECEIVE THE RESULTS OF THEIR PATIENTS LABS AND WRITTEN REPORTS OF THEIR PATIENTS EYE EXAMS. GOALS: (1) TO PROVIDE NUTRITION AND DIABETES EDUCATION TO THOSE PATIENTS WHO PRESENT WITH DIABETES TO THE DIABETES TREATMENT CENTER AS WELL AS INDIVIDUALS WHO ARE IDENTIFIED AT RISK FOR DIABETES AT HEALTH FAIRS OR OTHER COMMUNITY WELLNESS EVENTS. (2) MEET 60TH PERCENTILE FOR JFK ACO (AKA MEDICARE SHARED SAVINGS PROGRAM) DIABETES CARE QUALITY MEASURERS FOR JFK MEDICAL CENTER MEDICARE SHARED SAVINGS PLAN PARTICIPANTS. CURRENT VALUE: BELOW 30TH PERCENTILE (BASED ON 2015 DATA). - 2017: MEET OR EXCEED 40TH PERCENTILE FOR JFK MSSP DIABETES QUALITY MEASURES BASED ON 2016 DATA. - 2018: MEET OR EXCEED 50TH PERCENTILE FOR JFK MSSP DIABETES QUALITY MEASURES BASED ON 2017 DATA. - 2019: MEET OR EXCEED 60TH PERCENTILE FOR JFK MSSP DIABETES QUALITY MEASURES BASED ON 2018 DATA. CANCER/MAMMOGRAPHY SCREENING --------------------------------------------------------- JFK CANCER CARE PROGRAM IS ACCREDITED THROUGH THE COMMISSION ON CANCER. JFK BREAST CENTER EMPLOYS A PART-TIME OUTREACH COORDINATOR TO PROVIDE MAMMOGRAPHY AWARENESS AND PROMOTE ACCESS. THE CENTER PROVIDES ACCESS TO SCREENING SERVICES FROM 7 A.M. TO 8 P.M. DURING THE WEEK, AND ON SATURDAY MORNINGS. JFK OFFERS FREE MEDICAL TRANSPORTATION SERVICES FOR UNION COUNTY RESIDENTS TO ACCESS PRESCHEDULED MAMMOGRAPHY SCREENINGS AT JFK. UNION COUNTY RESIDENTS RATES OF MAMMOGRAM ACCESS ARE LOWER THAN THE STATE AVERAGE. GOALS: (1) IMPROVE MAMMOGRAPHY SCREENING AWARENESS FOR UNION COUNTY RESIDENTS BY INCREASING OUTREACH AND COMMUNITY EDUCATION. - 2017: ASSESS JFK MAMMOGRAPHY SCREENING OUTREACH IN UNION COUNTY AND DEVELOP PLANS TO IMPROVE OUTREACH AND COMMUNITY EDUCATION ABOUT MAMMOGRAPHY SCREENING BY FIVE PERCENT BY 2019. - 2018: IMPROVE UNION COUNTY OUTREACH AND COMMUNITY EDUCATION ABOUT MAMMOGRAPHY SCREENING BY TWO PERCENT OVER BASE YEAR. - 2019: IMPROVE UNION COUNTY OUTREACH AND COMMUNITY EDUCATION ABOUT MAMMOGRAPHY SCREENING BY FIVE PERCENT OVER BASE YEAR. CARDIAC/HEART DISEASE -------------------------------------- IN THE MEDICARE POPULATION, THE HEART FAILURE RATES ARE HIGHER IN THE JFK PSA THAN IN THE STATE AND US. JFK HAS INSTITUTED A PROGRAM TO PROVIDE HEART FAILURE PATIENTS WITH INDIVIDUALIZED TAILORED DISEASE SPECIFIC EDUCATION THAT PROMOTES HEALTHIER PATIENTS. THIS JFK RE-ENGINEERED DISCHARGE PROGRAMS GOAL IS TO EDUCATE AND EMPOWER PATIENTS AND THEIR FAMILIES TO BE ABLE TO MANAGE THEIR MEDICAL CONDITION AT HOME BY LEARNING TO IDENTIFY EARLY SIGNS AND SYMPTOMS AND KNOWING WHAT TO DO OR WHEN TO CONTACT A PHYSICIAN. DURING AND AFTER A PATIENTS HOSPITAL STAY, A MULTIDISCIPLINARY TEAM WILL ENSURE THAT PATIENTS HAVE THE TOOLS FOR A SMOOTH, HIGH QUALITY, SAFE AND EFFECTIVE TRANSITION FROM DISCHARGE TO HOME. THE PROCESS INCLUDES EDUCATION OF DIAGNOSIS, TREATMENTS, MEDICATIONS, DIETARY AND LIFESTYLE MODIFICATIONS, DISCHARGE PLANNING, ASSISTANCE WITH FOLLOW UP APPOINTMENTS, AS WELL AS POST DISCHARGE TELEPHONIC REINFORCEMENT AND TROUBLESHOOTING. GOALS: (1) REDUCE HOSPITAL HEART FAILURE READMISSIONS BY TEN PERCENT BY 2019 POPULATION HEALTH FOCUS #3: CONTINUITY OF CARE FOR VULNERABLE POPULATIONS ==============

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Part V, Section B
ExplntnTxt: The Community Health Needs Assessment (CHNA) was conducted from February to October of 2016 with the purpose of gathering information about local health needs and health behaviors. The assessment used both primary and secondary research to illustrate and compare health trends and disparities across the region. Primary research solicited input from key community stakeholders representing the broad interests of the community, including experts in public health and individuals representing medically underserved, low-income, and minority populations. Secondary research identified demographic and health trends across geographic areas and populations. The Cooper Board of Trustees met on December 21, 2016 to review the findings of the CHNA and the recommended implementation strategy. The board voted to adopt the final summary report and the implementation strategy and provide the necessary resources and support to carry out the initiatives therein. Question 5: The Burlington, Camden, Gloucester, and Ocean County Health Departments participated in the design and completion of Cooper's Community Health Needs Assessment, including meetings to identify and prioritize health needs. Specific research methods: - A review of secondary health and socioeconomic indicators for the service area. - An analysis and comparison of hospital utilization data. - Partner forums with community representatives and leaders to identify community health priorities and facilitate population health strategy collaboration. - Focus groups with health consumers. Question 6: The Health Assessment Collaborative included the following partners: Cooper University Hospital, Deborah Heart and Lung Center, Kennedy Health System, Lourdes Health System, Virtua Health, and the Health Departments of Burlington, Camden, Gloucester, and Ocean Counties. Question 10A: WWW.COOPERHEALTH.ORG/SITES/COOPER/FILES/SITE/PDF/CHNA-2016.PDF Question 11: A voting system based on the criteria of scope, severity, and ability to impact was used to help participants in the assessment prioritize local health needs. The prioritized list of health needs is as follows: 1. behavioral health and chronic disease comorbidities 2. linkages to care - access 3. substance abuse Cooper is addressing the significant needs identified in the recently conducted CHNA as follows: Behavioral health/chronic disease comorbidities: -creation of an advanced care center with implementation of an innovative multidisciplinary group visit model -Patients with similar diagnoses meet together and learn best practices of care together -community education programs and support groups linkages to care - access: -partnered with a third party vendor to assist patients in completing applications for financial assistance, medicaid, etc. -trained staff as certified application counselors to assist patients in obtaining insurance -launched urgent care services in three locations -implemented dedicated schedule slots with primary care physicians to ensure available follow-up appointments for patients within two weeks after hospital discharge Substance abuse: -implemented standardized, systematic mental health screening for all patients admitted to Cooper -launched an initiative to address the gaps in behavioral health resources and identify partnership opportunities in service provision -hosted and supported many community events in collaboration with the county's addiction awareness task force Rationale for community health needs not specifically addressed: Cooper recognizes that partnerships with community agencies have the broadest reach to improve community health issues. While additional disease specific and population specific needs were identified, the group found that other resources, such as the Southern New Jersey Perinatal Cooperative and disease specific resources were available and the health systems would be more effective in utilizing the available resources in addressing the prioritized needs. Question 16: WWW.COOPERHEALTH.ORG/PATIENT-GUIDE/FINANCIAL-MATTERS

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: THEDACARE REGIONAL MEDICAL CENTER - NEENAH, INC.
ExplntnTxt: Part V, Section B, Line 5: ThedaCare utilizes models created by the University of Wisconsin Population Health Institute and the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation as the framework for the Community Health Needs Assessment. Over the course of a one year period, secondary data was collected, public health and key informant interviews were conducted, ThedaCare CHAT (Community Health Action Team) provided input and patient health data was studied. Vulnerable populations included those living in poverty, rural farm families, the elderly, veterans, Hispanics/Latino's, LGBT, Hmong and African American. Input was collected by representatives of:- Rural Health Initiative- Casa Hispana- Aging and disability Resource Center of Outagamie County- Hmong-American Partnership- Outagamie County Veterans' Service - African Heritage, Inc.- LGBT Partnership

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: THEDACARE REGIONAL MEDICAL CENTER - NEENAH, INC.
ExplntnTxt: Part V, Section B, Line 11: The ThedaCare Community Health Implementation Strategy was approved by the ThedaCare Board of Trustees in December of 2016.- ThedaCare provides support to the Center for Healthcare Value which is coordinating efforts across the country to share quality improvement and cost reduction learnings. - ThedaCare partners with Affinity Health System to sponsor Mosiac Health, providing hands on experience for medical students.- ThedaCare also partners with area nursing schools such as UW Oshkosh and Fox Valley Technical College to provide professional mentors for their nursing programs and venues for nursing students to practice their skills.- ThedaCare hospitals provide financial as well as diagnostic and lab support to two area clinics providing medical and dental care to the underserved in our service area.- ThedaCare supports the End of Life Coalition- ThedaCare employees take part in Helping Hearts, an employee volunteerism program encouraging staff to give of their time in the community. ThedaCare provides paid staff to coordinate the program and identify and promote volunteerism opportunities. Obesity:- ThedaCare supports Weight of the Fox Valley - a four healthcare system approach to tackling obesity in Calumet, Outagamie and Winnegaco Counties, with financial contributions and participation on the leadership and core teams. Using the collective impact approach, Weight of the Fox Valley workgroups include Active Communities, Worksite, Early Care and Education, Food System, Healthcare and school. - Provides funding to local Farmer's Markets including Neenah.- ThedaCare partners with local YMCA's to educate children about eating healthy and the benefits of being active.- Good to Go Week is an annual employee led initiative that takes place in 6 school districts throughout the ThedaCare system. Activities include healthy snacks, build a school garden, fats in foods, measure your drink, leading gym classes.Mental Health/AODA:- ThedaCare financially supports the New Mental Health Connection which connects stakeholders and resources to improve the mental health of our community- Provides leadership and financial support for Catalpa Health, dedicated to pediatric mental health. - Provides leadership and funding for the Fox Valley Partnership Community Health Center working to improve the health status of the medically underserved by providing comprehensive primary care services.- Provided over $2,000,000 in subsidized mental health services. - Developed a protocol for screening patients for substance abuse and a policy for those on long-term opiate use. - Have gone live with the Wisconsin Prescription Drug Monitoring Program.- Have developed a policy for medical assisted treatment including Vivitrol. - ThedaCare annually sponsors Party at the PAC for thousands of area youth to educate on the perils of risky behavior while texting/drinking and driving. Early Childhood/Youth- ThedaCare is a supporter of the Reach out and Read Program.Poverty- ThedaCare is a partner with The Poverty Outcomes & Improvement Team (POINT), an 18 month initiative equipping the region with continuous improvement methodologies focused on poverty. POINT is using these processes to strengthen existing poverty reduction efforts, address service gaps, and measure progress on reducing poverty in Northeast Wisconsin.Health Disparities:- Opportunity Gap working to close the graduation gap between Black and White students in the Appleton and Menasha school districts.- Diversity and Inclusion working to establish a Diverse and Inclusive Business Council through the Fox Cities Chamber. Also, working to establish a more welcoming downtown Appleton for people of color. End of Life:- ThedaCare is part of the Fox Valley Advanced Care Planning Coalition, a partnership of Mosiac Family Health, Ascension Medical System and ThedaCare Medical System.Identified but not addressed:- Smoking: Existing efforts are under way- Homelessness: Beyond scope of resources- STD's: Beyond scope of resources

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Roper Hospital
ExplntnTxt: Part V, Section B, Line 5: In an effort to create a greater impact on the community and address the greatest needs, Roper St Francis produced a joint CHNA in collaboration with the Medical University of South Carolina and the Trident United Way. To gather community input the Community Health Needs Assessment team disseminated a community survey with the purpose of identifying a general overview of the most concerning health topics. The survey included over 900 respondents, a 173% increase over the last CHNA cycle and an immediate benefit of collaborating with community partners. In addition, the team hosted two health forums, facilitated 7 community focus groups, and conducted eight interviews with local healthcare, social service, and civic leaders. Respondents who participated in this phase included experts in the field of public health, hospital administration members, community outreach groups, and other local organizations. Using feedback from the survey, interviews and focus groups, a summary of community input was created. This summary would eventually be used to help focus in on priorities and ultimately, implementation strategies.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Roper Hospital
ExplntnTxt: Part V, Section B, Line 6a: Roper St. Francis Healthcare produced a joint CHNA report in collaboration with its three Charleston area hospitals, as well as the Medical University of South Carolina and the Trident United Way. A major accomplishment of this collaborative effort was to recognize a set of common priorities, design programs that address the greatest needs, and create the greatest impact to improve the health and wellbeing of our community. Given different missions, goals and government requirements, the organizations individually prioritized health needs and corresponding support programs and services. The Rope St Francis facilities include Roper Hospital, Bon Secours St Francis Hospital, and Mount Pleasant Hospital. Each of these hospitals files a Schedule H and has a customized implementation plan.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Roper Hospital
ExplntnTxt: Part V, Section B, Line 6b: See response above to question 6a.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: Roper Hospital
ExplntnTxt: Part V, Section B, Line 11: Roper St Francis used the Healthy People 2020 rankings reported in the survey and qualitative data collection methods to establish its current priorities. To ensure the priorities selected were strategically aligned with Roper St. Francis' mission and vision, priority was determined based on the system's ability to impact an identified need to the significance of the need in the community. As part of the prioritization process, Roper St. Francis Healthcare conducted an inventory of existing system-based outreach programs, community partnerships, and other collaborative resources that currently address each of the priority areas:After examining the range of services currently available, the expertise, outreach, and capacity of the RSFH system, and the resources available to best address needs through other community organizations, Roper St. Francis Healthcare senior leadership chose the following 5 issues as priorities to implement for its current CHNA: Access to Care; Clinical Preventive Services; Mental Health; Obesity/Nutrition/Physical Activity; Social Determinants; and Maternal, Infant, and Child Health.For the Healthy People 2020 topics that were not identified through the CHNA as strategic priority areas of need (Injury and Violence; Substance Abuse; Environmental Quality; Oral Health; Sexual Health; Tobacco Use), Roper St. Francis Healthcare is committed to providing support and collaboratively working with local partners, new and existing, to ensure these needs are acknowledged.The Roper St. Francis Community Needs Assessment Team developed implementation strategies for each health issue identified as a strategic priority. This implementation plan will be rolled out over the next 3 years. Strategies are be clearly defined with a matrix of which areas each RSFH hospital will address. Some strategies may be addressed by more than one RSFH hospital or the system as a whole. The team will develop a monitoring method at the conclusion of the implementation planning process to provide status updates to community partners, stakeholders, and the community-at-large.The Community Health Needs Assessment for fiscal December 31, 2016 was approved by the Board of Directors at its meeting held on October 15, 2016.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: THE PRESBYTERIAN HOSPITAL PART V, SECTION B, LINE 5:
ExplntnTxt: WHILE CONDUCTING THE CHNA, THE HOSPITAL FACILITY(IES) SOLICITED INPUT FROM, AND CONSULTED WITH, A VARIETY OF COMMUNITY REPRESENTATIVES INCLUDING, BUT NOT LIMITED TO, REPRESENTATIVES OF CITY AND COUNTY GOVERNMENT INCLUDING HEALTH DEPARTMENTS, COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATIONS, FOUNDATIONS, CHURCHES, COLLEGES/UNIVERSITIES, COMMUNITY COALITIONS AND OTHER SOCIAL SERVICE AGENCIES. INPUT WAS GATHERED THROUGH COMMUNITY MEETINGS, STAKEHOLDERS INTERVIEWS, AND SOLICITED THROUGH WRITTEN COMMENTS THROUGHOUT THE SURVEY PERIOD UNTIL THE FINAL COMMUNITY PRIORITY SETTING MEETING(S) AND SURVEY. THE SCOPE OF EXPERTISE WAS BROAD AND INCLUDED SUCH AREAS AS PUBLIC HEALTH, MINORITY POPULATIONS, HEALTH DISPARITIES, AND SOCIAL SERVICES. THE ORGANIZATION IS A PART OF NOVANT HEALTH, AN INTEGRATED NOT-FOR-PROFIT HEALTH SYSTEM. AS SUCH, NOVANT HEALTH INCLUDES MULTIPLE HOSPITAL FACILITIES AND HAS ENGAGED IN CHNAS FOR ALL OF THE COMMUNITIES BEING SERVED. WHERE POSSIBLE, WE HAVE LEVERAGED THE RESOURCES OF THE ORGANIZATION TO BEST ADDRESS THOSE NEEDS THAT ARE HIGHEST IN PRIORITY AND CONSISTENT ACROSS COMMUNITIES.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: THE PRESBYTERIAN HOSPITAL PART V, SECTION B, LINE 11:
ExplntnTxt: THE HOSPITAL FACILITY(IES) IS/ARE A PART OF NOVANT HEALTH, AN INTEGRATED NOT-FOR-PROFIT HEALTH SYSTEM. AS SUCH, NOVANT HEALTH INCLUDES MULTIPLE HOSPITAL FACILITIES AND HAS ENGAGED IN CHNAS FOR ALL OF THE COMMUNITIES BEING SERVED. THE FACILITY'S CHNA IDENTIFIED MULTIPLE NEEDS FOR THE COMMUNITY SERVED. THE NEEDS IDENTIFIED WERE REVIEWED AND PRIORITIZED BY THE CHNA RESOURCE GROUP AND SUBSEQUENTLY BY EACH FACILITY'S BOARD. THEY EVALUATED EACH DOCUMENTED NEED AND ITS INTERSECTION WITH THE ORGANIZATION'S VISION, COMMITMENTS, AND KEY STRENGTHS BEFORE FURTHER PRIORITIZING THE HEALTH NEEDS AND AGREEING UPON THE TOP HEALTH PRIORITIES TO BE ADDRESSED. WHERE POSSIBLE, WE HAVE LEVERAGED THE SYSTEM'S STRENGTHS AND RESOURCES TO BEST ADDRESS THOSE NEEDS THAT ARE HIGHEST IN PRIORITY AND CONSISTENT ACROSS COMMUNITIES. NOVANT HEALTH AND EACH OF ITS HOSPITAL FACILITIES HAVE ADOPTED AND EXECUTED AN IMPLEMENTATION STRATEGY THAT ADDRESSES THE PRIORITIZED COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS FROM THE CHNAS. THE IMPLEMENTATION STRATEGIES OUTLINE THE PLAN THAT THE HOSPITAL FACILITY(IES) WILL UNDERTAKE TO MEET THOSE HEALTH NEEDS IN EACH OF ITS COMMUNITIES. CERTAIN NEEDS THAT WERE IDENTIFIED BY THE CHNA HAVE NOT BEEN ADDRESSED. IT WAS DETERMINED THAT THERE ARE OTHER RESOURCES IN THE COMMUNITY THAT CAN MORE APPROPRIATELY ADDRESS THESE NEEDS BASED ON SCOPE OF SERVICES AND SKILL SET. FOR MORE DETAILED INFORMATION, REFER TO THE PUBLICLY AVAILABLE IMPLEMENTATION PLAN AVAILABLE ON THE WEBSITE; REFER TO THE URL GIVEN PREVIOUSLY FOR THE POSTING OF THE PLAN.

ExplntnTxt: IT IS POSSIBLE FOR A FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE POLICY (FAP) ELIGIBLE PATIENT TO BE CHARGED AN AMOUNT EQUAL TO THE GROSS CHARGE FOR A NON-EMERGENCY OR NON-MEDICALLY NECESSARY SERVICE. HOWEVER, IF THE SERVICE IS DEEMED AN EMERGENCY OR A MEDICAL NECESSITY, THEN THE FAP ELIGIBLE PATIENT WOULD NOT BE CHARGED FOR CARE AND WOULD NOT RECEIVE A BILL ONCE FAP ELIGIBILITY HAD BEEN ESTABLISHED.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SAMARITAN MEDICAL CENTER
ExplntnTxt: PART V, SECTION B, LINE 5: SAMARITAN MEDICAL CENTER'S 2016 COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS ASSESSMENT (CHNA) WAS PREPARED BY THE FORT DRUM REGIONAL HEALTH PLANNING ORGANIZATION (FDRHPO) IN COLLABORATION WITH NORTH COUNTRY HEALTH COMPASS PARTNERS (NCHCP). THE LATTER GROUP IS AN FDRHPO-ALIGNED COALITION OF REPRESENTATIVES FROM HOSPITALS, COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENTS AND AGENCIES, AND COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATIONS WORKING TOGETHER TO DEVELOP, IMPLEMENT AND EVALUATE HEALTH IMPROVEMENT INITIATIVES WITHIN A THREE-COUNTY REGION. NCHCP MEMBERS, WHO MEET MONTHLY, PROVIDED INPUT AND FEEDBACK THROUGHOUT THE CHNA'S DEVELOPMENT. THOSE WITH SPECIAL KNOWLEDGE AND EXPERTISE IN PUBLIC HEALTH WHO WERE INVOLVED IN THE PROCESS INCLUDED THE JEFFERSON COUNTY PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE'S DIRECTOR AND PUBLIC HEALTH PLANNER; LEWIS COUNTY PUBLIC HEALTH'S DIRECTOR AND SUPERVISING PUBLIC HEALTH NURSE, AND THE ST. LAWRENCE COUNTY PUBLIC HEALTH DEPARTMENT'S DIRECTOR AND PREVENTIVE SERVICES DIRECTOR. SAMARITAN'S SERVICE AREA COVERS ALL OF JEFFERSON COUNTY AND ADJACENT PORTIONS OF LEWIS AND ST. LAWRENCE COUNTIES; THE INDIVIDUALS FROM THE HEALTH DEPARTMENTS OF THESE THREE COUNTIES REPRESENT THE BROAD INTERESTS OF RESIDENTS LIVING IN THE COMMUNITIES SERVED BY SAMARITAN MEDICAL CENTER.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SAMARITAN MEDICAL CENTER
ExplntnTxt: PART V, SECTION B, LINE 6A: OTHER HOSPITAL FACILITIES PARTICIPATING IN THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE CHNA, IN ADDITION TO SAMARITAN, WERE: CARTHAGE AREA HOSPITAL AND RIVER HOSPITAL IN JEFFERSON COUNTY; LEWIS COUNTY GENERAL HOSPITAL IN LEWIS COUNTY AND CLAXTON-HEPBURN MEDICAL CENTER, CLIFTON-FINE HOSPITAL AND E.J. NOBLE HOSPITAL/GOUVERNEUR IN ST. LAWRENCE COUNTY. SAMARITAN IS A MEMBER OF THE HOSPITAL ASSOCIATION OF NEW YORK STATE, WHICH ANNUALLY GENERATES AN ECONOMIC AND COMMUNITY IMPACT REPORT FOR SAMARITAN MEDICAL CENTER INDICATING IN TOTAL DOLLARS THE COST OF CARE THE HOSPITAL PROVIDED IN THE PRIOR YEAR TO PEOPLE IN NEED, SUBSIDIZED CARE AND SERVICES TO LOW-INCOME, ELDERLY AND UNDER-SERVED COMMUNITIES, AND THE HOSPITAL'S INVESTMENT IN COMMUNITY HEALTH INITIATIVES. IN ADDITION TO THIS AMOUNT, THE REPORT INDICATES THE NUMBER OF OUTPATIENTS TREATED, EMERGENCY ROOM VISITS, HOSPITAL ADMISSIONS AND BABIES DELIVERED DURING THAT YEAR, AS WELL THE NUMBER OF JOBS GENERATED. THIS REPORT ALSO PROVIDES AN ESTIMATE IN DOLLARS OF THE ANNUAL ECONOMIC ACTIVITY AND TAX DOLLARS GENERATED IN THE COMMUNITY DUE TO THE HOSPITAL'S PRESENCE AND SPENDING. THIS INFORMATION, AS WELL AS MORE DETAIL, IS INCLUDED IN SAMARITAN'S ANNUAL REPORT TO THE COMMUNITY, A PUBLICATION WHICH IS MAILED TO KEY HOSPITAL AND COMMUNITY STAKEHOLDERS AND ALSO PUBLICLY AVAILABLE ON THE HOSPITAL'S WEBSITE.

LAWRENCE COUNTIES, WITH COORDINATION AND CHNA OVERSIGHT PROVIDED BY THE FORT DRUM REGIONAL HEALTH PLANNING ORGANIZATION. LAWRENCE-LEWIS BOARD OF COOPERATIVE EDUCATIONAL SERVICES, ST. LAWRENCE COUNTY COMMUNITY SERVICES, SEAWAY VALLEY PREVENTION COUNCIL, UNITED HEALTH GROUP, WATERTOWN CHAMBER OF COMMERCE AND WATERTOWN FAMILY YMCA.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: SAMARITAN MEDICAL CENTER
ExplntnTxt: PART V, SECTION B, LINE 11: SAMARITAN MEDICAL CENTER IS A PARTNER WITH THE FORT DRUM REGIONAL PLANNING ORGANIZATION (FDRHPO), WHICH PROVIDES LEADERSHIP IN PLANNING AND COORDINATING REGIONAL HEALTH CARE INITIATIVES AND A LEADING MEMBER OF THE NORTH COUNTRY INITIATIVE (NCI), A CONSORTIUM OF HOSPITALS, PHYSICIANS AND OTHER HEALTH CARE PROVIDERS WORKING TO REFORM AND IMPROVE THE DELIVERY OF QUALITY HEALTHCARE THROUGHOUT OUR TRI-COUNTY AREA. THE HOSPITAL IS AN ACTIVE PARTICIPANT IN THE FDRHPO'S NORTH COUNTRY HEALTH COMPASS PARTNERS (NCHCP), A COALITION OF MORE THAN 40 PUBLIC HEALTH DEPARTMENTS, HEALTHCARE FACILITIES AND AGENCIES, AND COMMUNITY-BASED ORGANIZATIONS WORKING TO IMPROVE THE REGION'S POPULATION HEALTH THROUGH COORDINATED SUPPORT OF NEW YORK STATE'S MANY POPULATION HEALTH IMPROVEMENT INITIATIVES. KEY WORK OF THE NCHCP IS TO ASSESS AND IMPROVE POPULATION HEALTH FOR THE 250,000 PEOPLE LIVING WITHIN THE TRI-COUNTY REGION, STRENGTHEN THE POPULATION HEALTH INFRASTRUCTURE, IMPROVE ACCESS TO PRIMARY AND PREVENTION CARE, AND FOCUS ON ELIMINATING HEALTH DISPARITIES. FDRHPO/NCHCP UNDERTOOK THE 2016 COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS ASSESSMENT. DATA ASSEMBLED FROM A VARIETY OF STATE, FEDERAL AND LOCAL SOURCES - INCLUDING A REGIONAL COMMUNITY SURVEY - WERE COMPARED AND EVALUATED TO IDENTIFY DISPARITIES AND SIGNIFICANT ISSUES IMPACTING REGIONAL, AS WELL AS COUNTY-WIDE, POPULATION HEALTH. THE 2016 CHNA FOR JEFFERSON COUNTY (SAMARITAN'S PRIMARY SERVICE AREA) WERE AS FOLLOWS: " HIGH AND GROWING OBESITY RATES FOR ADULTS AND CHILDREN: TWO-THIRD OF ADULTS AND TWO-FIFTHS OF CHILDREN WERE IDENTIFIED AS OBESE OR OVERWEIGHT (2013-14 FIGURES). OBESITY IS A RISK FACTOR FOR HEART DISEASE, STROKE, CANCER IN MANY FORMS, DIABETES AND KIDNEY DISEASE, AND COULD OVERTAKE CANCER AS THE LEADING CAUSE OF PREVENTABLE DEATHS IN THE NEXT DECADE. " HOSPITALIZATIONS FOR SHORT-TIME DIABETES COMPLICATIONS ALMOST DOUBLED BETWEEN 2011 AND 2014. " THE CIGARETTE SMOKING RATE SHOWED A NON-SIGNIFICANT DECREASE SINCE THE LAST COMMUNITY ASSESSMENT, BUT REMAINS SIGNIFICANTLY HIGHER THAN THE NEW YORK STATE RATE. " THE RATE OF COLORECTAL CANCER SCREENING REMAINED BELOW NYS TARGETS." THE AREA'S SUICIDE RATE REMAINED HIGHER THAN STATEWIDE AND REGIONAL BENCHMARKS." ADULTS REPORTING BINGE DRINKING GREW BY SIX PERCENTAGE POINTS BETWEEN 2011 AND 2014, WITH 2014 RATE MORE THAN 7% HIGHER THAN THE STATE RATE." THE PERCENTAGE OF RESIDENTS SERVED BY OPTIMALLY FLUORIDATED COMMUNITY WATER SYSTEMS FELL FROM 79% TO 71% PERCENT BETWEEN 2012 AND 2015." THE PERCENTAGE OF CHILDREN IN PUBLIC INSURANCE PROGRAMS WITH RECOMMENDED WELL-CHILD VISITS REMAINED LOWER COMPARED TO THE STATEWIDE AVERAGE, ALTHOUGH THE RATE FOR ALL AGE GROUPS INCREASED SIX PERCENTAGE POINTS." DESPITE A SMALL DECREASE FROM 2011, THE 2014 PERCENTAGE OF UNINTENDED PREGNANCIES, AT 33% OF LIVE BIRTHS, REMAINED HIGHER THAN THE STATEWIDE AVERAGE OF 26.5%." THE PERCENTAGE OF WOMEN AGED 13-17 WITH HPV IMMUNIZATIONS REMAINED LOW, WITH ONLY 15.9% IMMUNIZED COMPARED TO 30.3% FOR THE STATE EXCLUDING NEW YORK CITY." ABOUT ONE-FIFTH OF JEFFERSON COUNTY RESIDENTS DO NOT HAVE A REGULAR HEALTH CARE PROVIDER. THIS IS HIGHER THAN THE STATEWIDE RATE OF 16%, AND WELL SHORT OF THE NEW YORK STATE'S PREVENTION AGENDA 2018 OBJECTIVE OF LESS THAN 10%. JEFFERSON COUNTY HAS FEWER PRIMARY CARE CLINICIANS PER POPULATION COMPARED TO THE STATEWIDE RATE.HOSPITALS AND COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENTS PARTICIPATING IN THE CHNA MET AT COUNTY LEVELS TO DISCUSS THE IDENTIFIED ISSUES AND PRIORITIZE NEEDS IN ALIGNMENT WITH THE NEW YORK STATE HEALTH DEPARTMENT'S PREVENTION AGENDA, CHOOSING SPECIFIC PRIORITIES TO MUTUALLY TACKLE. THESE COMMON PRIORITIES WERE THEN ADDRESSED BY EACH ORGANIZATION IN ITS OWN THREE-YEAR COMMUNITY SERVICE PLAN (CSP). IN DETERMINING WHICH PRIORITIES TO WORK ON, THESE COLLABORATING INSTITUTIONS CONSIDERED NOT ONLY THE ISSUES AND DISPARITIES, BUT THE IMPACT THESE DISPARITIES AND THEIR POSSIBLE SOLUTIONS MIGHT HAVE ON OTHER HEALTH OUTCOMES; AVAILABLE RESOURCES; EASE OF SOLUTION IMPLEMENTATION; LEADERSHIP SUPPORT AVAILABLE, AND IMPORTANCE TO THE PUBLIC HEALTH SYSTEM. ULTIMATELY, THOSE COMMUNITY NEEDS NOT DIRECTLY ADDRESSED IN THE COMMUNITY SERVICE PLAN WERE SIMPLY OF A LOWER PRIORITY, NOT ACHIEVABLE IN A REASONABLE TIMEFRAME OR DID NOT HAVE THE ADEQUATE RESOURCES AVAILABLE TO EFFECTIVELY IMPACT THE NEED. JEFFERSON COUNTY'S PUBLIC HEALTH DEPARTMENT AND THREE HOSPITALS AGREED TO WORK ON THE FOLLOWING TWO NYS PREVENTION AGENDA PRIORITIES DURING THE 2016-2018 CSP PERIOD: (1) PREVENT CHRONIC DISEASE, WITH A FOCUS ON REDUCING OBESITY IN CHILDREN AND ADULTS IN ORDER TO ADDRESS DISPARITIES RELATED TO HIGH OBESITY RATES AND DIABETES COMPLICATIONS AND (2) PROMOTE MENTAL HEALTH AND PREVENT SUBSTANCE ABUSE, WITH A FOCUS ON STRENGTHENING INFRASTRUCTURE ACROSS SYSTEMS, IN ORDER TO TACKLE DISPARITIES RELATED TO SUICIDE RATES AND SUBSTANCE ABUSE.SAMARITAN'S CSP OUTLINES THE FOLLOWING SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES, INTERVENTIONS AND STRATEGIES. TO REDUCE OBESITY, THE HOSPITAL WILL: (1) PROVIDE COMMUNITY-BASED NUTRITION EDUCATION AND HEALTHY COOKING DEMONSTRATION CLASSES TO THE PUBLIC THROUGH SAMARITAN'S NETWORK OF SEVEN COMMUNITY-BASED PRIMARY CLINICS LOCATED THROUGHOUT THE HOSPITAL'S SERVICE AREA AND (2) IMPLEMENT AN AMERICAN ACADEMY OF DIABETES EDUCATION-ACCREDITED DIABETES SELF-MANAGEMENT EDUCATION PROGRAM, OFFERING CLASSES TO DIABETES AND PRE-DIABETES PATIENTS AND THEIR FAMILY MEMBERS. TO STRENGTHEN BEHAVIORAL HEALTH INFRASTRUCTURE, SAMARITAN WILL: (1) SCREEN ALL PATIENTS AT EACH OF THE HOSPITAL'S SEVEN PRIMARY CLINICS AT LEAST ONCE ANNUALLY FOR DEPRESSION USING PHQ-2 AND PHQ-9 COMPONENTS OF THE PATIENT HEALTH QUESTIONNAIRE, AND ESTABLISH SCREENING, BRIEF INTERVENTION AND REFERRAL TO TREATMENT (SBIRT) PROCEDURES IN EACH CLINIC TO ENSURE PATIENTS ARE SCREENED FOR SUBSTANCE ABUSE RISK BEHAVIORS AND REFERRED FOR ADDITIONAL SERVICES AS NECESSARY AND (2) LOCATE A FULL- OR PART-TIME NYS-LICENSED CLINICAL SOCIAL WORKER (LCSW) IN EACH OF THE HOSPITAL'S SEVEN PRIMARY CARE CLINICS TO SUPPORT AND ASSIST MENTAL HEALTH PATIENTS AND THEIR FAMILIES. IN ADDITION TO THESE SPECIFIC ACTIVITIES, SAMARITAN WILL CONTINUE TO PARTICIPATE ON REGIONAL COMMITTEES AND IN INITIATIVES COORDINATED BY FDRHPO AND NCI THAT ADDRESS AREAS RELATIVE TO CHRONIC AND BEHAVIORAL HEALTH ISSUES, AS WELL AS PARTNER WITH THESE AND OTHER COMMUNITY PROVIDERS AND AGENCIES ON PROJECTS ADDRESSING ADDITIONAL REGIONAL POPULATION HEALTH CONCERNS THAT ARE NOT SPECIFICALLY TACKLED IN THE CURRENT CSP. THESE ONGOING ACTIVITIES INCLUDE PREVENTION AND AWARENESS EDUCATION ON THE REGION'S MOST PREVALENT CHRONIC DISEASES AND CONDITIONS, EARLY CANCER DETECTION SCREENINGS, SMOKING CESSATION CLASSES, PARTICIPATION IN AND SUPPORT FOR REGIONAL HEALTH CAMPAIGNS, PHYSICIAN RECRUITMENT/RETENTION ACTIVITIES, ADOPTION OF EVIDENCE-BASED MEDICAL AND CLINICAL IMPROVEMENTS TO ENHANCE PATIENT OUTCOMES, AND DEVELOPMENT OF TELEMEDICINE INFRASTRUCTURE AND TOOLS TO IMPROVE THE ACCESS OF OUR REGION'S RURAL, UNDER-SERVED POPULATION TO COST-EFFECTIVE, QUALITY HEALTH CARE.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: ALLEN MEMORIAL HOSPITAL CORPORATION
ExplntnTxt: PART V, SECTION B, LINE 5: DATA AND OTHER INFORMATION USED IN THE 2017-2019 ASSESSMENT ARE DRAWN FROM INTERVIEWS, FOCUS GROUPS, THE COMMUNITY INTERVIEWS SURVEY, THE COMMUNITY ONLINE SURVEY, EXTERNAL COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS SURVEYS FROM THE DEFINED SURVEY AREA, AND EXTERNAL RESOURCES INCLUDING NEWSPAPERS, ONLINE SOURCES, MEETING NOTES, TELEVISION, WHITE PAPERS AND REPORTS.THE CORE OF THE COMMUNITY INTERVIEW SURVEY IS DATA GATHERED DURING 24 INTERVIEWS AND FOCUS GROUPS WITH LEADERS OF ORGANIZATIONS PROVIDING SOCIAL SERVICES, EDUCATION, PHILANTHROPY AND HEALTHCARE TO THE CEDAR VALLEY. INTERVIEWS WERE MADE FACE-TO-FACE ON SITE WITH EACH ORGANIZATION'S LEADER OR LEADERSHIP TEAM. INTERVIEWERS FRAMED THE SESSIONS WITH STANDARD QUESTIONS FOR CONTINUITY AND ENCOURAGED PARTICIPANTS TO OFFER THEIR OWN QUESTIONS, ANSWERS AND RECOMMENDATIONS. PARTICIPANTS IN EACH MEETING DEFINED AND PRIORITIZED COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS WITHOUT PROMPTING OR SUGGESTION. INTERVIEWS WERE CONDUCTED FROM DECEMBER 2015 - SEPTEMBER 2016 IN SESSIONS LASTING 60-90 MINUTES. SURVEY PARTICIPANTS REPRESENT THE INTERESTS OF AFRICAN AMERICAN, HISPANIC, BOSNIAN, ASIAN, INDIAN, BURMESE, AMERICAN INDIAN AND CONGOLESE POPULATIONS LIVING IN THE SURVEY AREA, PREDOMINATELY IN BLACK HAWK COUNTY. THEY ALSO REPRESENT THE INTERESTS AND SERVE RESIDENTS LIVING IN POVERTY; WOMEN AND CHILDREN; WOMEN AND CHILDREN AT RISK; PRE-SCHOOL CHILDREN; ADULTS 65+; THE DISABLED; THE UNDEREMPLOYED AND UNEMPLOYED; THE MEDICALLY-UNDERSERVED AND UNSERVED; RESIDENTS SUFFERING FROM MENTAL HEALTH AND/OR ADDICTION; RESIDENTS LIVING WITH FOOD INSECURITY; ENGLISH LANGUAGE LEARNERS AND THE LGBT COMMUNITIES. COMMUNITY SURVEY PARTICIPANTS WERE RECRUITED SPECIFICALLY FOR THEIR KNOWLEDGE AND RECORD OF SUCCESSFUL SERVICE TO ONE OR MORE MEDICALLY-UNDERSERVED, LOW-INCOME AND MINORITY POPULATIONS. THEY INCLUDE ALLEN CHILD PROTECTION CENTER; ALLEN COLLEGE ENGAGEMENT-SALVATION ARMY PARTNERSHIP FREE CLINIC; ALLEN WOMEN'S HEALTH CENTER; BIG BROTHERS BIG SISTERS OF NORTHEAST IOWA; BLACK HAWK COUNTY GAMING ASSOCIATION; BLACK HAWK-GRUNDY MENTAL HEALTH CENTER; CEDAR VALLEY FRIENDS OF THE FAMILY; CEDAR VALLEY'S PROMISE; CEDAR VALLEY UNITED WAY; COVENANT MIDWIVES AND WOMEN'S HEALTH CENTER; FAMILY AND CHILDREN'S COUNCIL; GUERNSEY CHARITABLE FOUNDATION; HAWKEYE COMMUNITY COLLEGE; HEALTHY CEDAR VALLEY COALITION; I-HOPE FREE CLINIC; KWWL-TV FOCUS GROUPS 1 AND 2; R.J. MCELROY TRUST; NORTHEAST IOWA FOOD BANK; SALVATION ARMY; SUCCESS LINK INC.; UNIVERSITY OF NORTHERN IOWA; WATERLOO COMMUNITY SCHOOLS; YWCA OF BLACK HAWK COUNTY.EXTERNAL RESOURCES FOR THIS REPORT ALSO INCLUDE 45 NEWSPAPER ARTICLES, 50 ONLINE ARTICLES, 2 TELEVISION REPORT TRANSCRIPTS AND 23 WHITE PAPERS AND REPORTS.THE ASSESSMENT ALSO INCLUDES RESULTS OF THE COMMUNITY ONLINE SURVEY CONDUCTED DECEMBER 1 - DECEMBER 20, 2015. THE SURVEY WAS SPONSORED AND IMPLEMENTED BY THE BLACK HAWK COUNTY HEALTH DEPARTMENT, UNITYPOINT HEALTH - WATERLOO (ALLEN HOSPITAL) AND WHEATON FRANCISCAN HEALTHCARE - IOWA (COVENANT MEDICAL CENTER AND SARTORI MEMORIAL HOSPITAL. THE ONLINE SURVEY DREW RESPONSES FROM 617 CEDAR VALLEY RESIDENTS, WHO INDIVIDUALLY IDENTIFIED AND PRIORITIZED COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS. RESULTS WERE COLLATED, TRANSCRIBED AND TABULATED FOR THIS REPORT.

FrmAndLnRfrncDsc: ALLEN MEMORIAL HOSPITAL CORPORATION
ExplntnTxt: PART V, SECTION B, LINE 11: THE 2017-2019 COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS ASSESSMENT IDENTIFIED EIGHT HEALTH NEEDS. SURVEY PARTICIPANTS RANKED THEM IN THIS PRIORITY: MENTAL HEALTH ACCESS AND SERVICES; HEALTHCARE ACCESS AND TRANSPORTATION; WOMEN AND CHILDREN'S HEALTH; NUTRITION, OBESITY AND WELLNESS; CHILD ABUSE AND NEGLECT; HEALTHCARE INSURANCE AND FINANCE; IMPROVING HIGH SCHOOL GRADUATION RATES IN WATERLOO; REDUCING TEEN GUN VIOLENCE IN WATERLOO.THE ALLEN HOSPITAL BOARD OF DIRECTORS DISCUSSED EIGHT COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS AT THE MARCH 28, 2017 BOARD MEETING. DIRECTORS THEN CAST INDIVIDUAL VOTES TO DECIDE WHICH THREE NEEDS TO PRIORITIZE IN THE 2017-2019 COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS IMPLEMENTATION PLAN.MENTAL HEALTH ACCESS AND SERVICES AND WOMEN'S AND CHILDREN'S HEALTH RANKED FIRST AND SECOND, WHILE NUTRITION, OBESITY AND WELLNESS RANKED THIRD.THE ALLEN HOSPITAL BOARD OF DIRECTORS DISCUSSED 29 POSSIBLE INITIATIVES TO ADDRESS THEIR COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS PRIORITIES AT ITS APRIL 25, 2017 BOARD MEETING. DIRECTORS THEN CAST INDIVIDUAL VOTES TO DECIDE WHICH 10 INITIATIVES TO CONTINUE OR ADOPT THROUGH JUNE 2018. REMAINING COMMUNITY HEALTH NEEDS WILL BE RECONSIDERED IN 2018 AND 2019. IN ORDER OF SUPPORT, THE 2017-2018 INITIATIVES INCLUDE::MENTAL HEALTH: SUPPORT ALLEN COLLEGE INITIATIVES TO PREPARE MORE PROVIDERS; ESTABLISH OPEN-ACCESS SCHEDULING AT BLACK HAWK GRUNDY MENTAL HEALTH CENTER; INTEGRATE SOCIAL WORKERS INTO FAMILY MEDICINE CLINICS; EXPAND TELEHEALTH CARE; EXPAND THERAPISTS AND THERAPY PROGRAMS IN METROPOLITAN SCHOOLS; JOINS BLACK HAWK COUNTY STEPPING UP INITIATIVE TO KEEP MENTAL HEALTH PATIENTS OUT OF JAIL; WORK WITH SALVATION ARMY AND LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT TO SLOW THE REVOLVING DOOR FOR MENTAL HEALTH PATIENTS.WOMEN AND CHILDREN'S HEALTH: ALIGN ALLEN WOMEN'S HEALTH, OB AND NICU TO CARE FOR MORE HIGH-RISK PREGNANCIES; PLACE CASE WORKERS WITH SUCCESS STREET IN METROPOLITAN SCHOOLS.NUTRITION, OBESITY, WELLNESS: STRENGTHEN STRATEGIC PARTNERSHIPS WITH EXISTING AGENCIES ADDRESSING THESE CONCERNS TO COLLABORATE RATHER THAN COMPETE; DEVELOP UPH-ALLEN HOSPITAL PHYSICIAN FORUMS WITH AREA CONGREGATIONS TO PROVIDE HEALTH EDUCATION.
